results.title: Hunting
results.brief_description: The power of seduction is explored in this dramatic thriller where corruption is rife in the business and political world. Media tycoon Michael Bergman (John Savage) meets a married executive secretary (Kerry Armstrong) and the two begin an affair. She, seduced by promises and material wealth, falls for Michael and moves into his mansion and life for good. Once part of his domain, however, like a moth to the flame (a literal image in the film) her new world starts to unravel. Written, directed and produced by Frank Howson. Cast includes Guy Pearce, Rebecca Rigg, Jeffrey Thomas, Rhys McConnochie, Nicholas Bell.

results.title: The Waterboy
results.creator_credit: Frank Coraci, Jack Giarraputo, Robert Simonds and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: In this comedic film of sight gags Adam Sandler plays the role of Bobby Boucher, a water boy for the local college football team. Bobby cops it from all directions - his over-bearing mother (Kathy Bates), the football team and even the coach (Jerry Reed). When the coach fires him, Bobby is forced to join the rival team under Coach Klein (Henry Winkler) where he turns his talents from water boy to a star tackler setting this losing team on the road to victory. Love, glory and revenge await Bobby as he takes up his new life as a football hero and college student. Cast includes Fairuza Balk, Blake Clark and Larry Gilliard Jr.

results.title: Here comes Mr. Jordan
results.creator_credit: Alexander Hall, Everett Riskin and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Joe Pendleton (Robert Montgomery), is a contender for the light heavyweight boxing crown, but is killed in a plane crash. An angel (Edward Everett Horton), realising the error that Joe has arrived in heaven 50 years too early. Trying to rectify the mistake, Mr. Jordon (Claude Rains), the chief deispatcher of the “Heavenly Express” sends Joe back to earth in the body of a just-murdered millionaire. This delightful romantic comedy was so successful, it inspired a musical sequel, “Down to Earth” and was remade as “Heaven can wait” in 1978.

results.title: New York, New York
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Erwin Winkler, Robert Chartoff and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: This stylised production of “New york, New York” pays homage to the nostalgic days of the classic Hollywood musical with one exception; the storyline is tinged with a dark side. It is V-J night, 1945; the setting is a ballroom in New York where young revellers are swinging and dancing the night away to the wonderful sounds of the big band music, and an embittered would-be sax player by the name of Jimmy Doyle (Robert De Niro) is determined to “get laid”. However the young USO singer, Francine (Liza Minnelli) who Doyle will not leave alone, has other ideas. Through the most unlikely circumstances, Jimmy and Francine meet up the next day and from there on in, their two lives become intertwined, he as a sax player and her as a singer, both in the same band. We follow the fortunes and misfortunes of their relationship and the insecurities as each strives to achieve success as an artist. It is hard to sympathise and empathise with the character of Jimmy Doyle. He is selfish, self-centred, volatile, frustratingly irritating, obsessive and possessive and one wonders how Francine could indeed be attracted to him in the first place. The best feature of this film is the music and particularly the title song, “New York, New York”. It received a mix reaction on its original release in 1977 but was more successful on its re-release in 1981 when footage that was originally cut from the film, including the legendary “Happy Endings” scene, was restored. Cast also includes Lionel Stander, Barry Primus, Mary Kay Place, Georgie Auld. Please note that this is the fully restored version of “New York, New York”.

results.title: The October man
results.creator_credit: Roy Baker, Alan Jaggs, Eric Ambler and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: In this powerful thriller, John Mills plays a lonely man who is recovering from a nervous breakdown. Through mysterious circumstances, he is suspected of a local murder and his past only confirms everyone’s suspicion of his guilt. His only hope is to prove his innocence himself. This superbly crafted movie benefits from a strong central performance by John Mills. The script, by Eric Ambler, could be a model for many of today’s thriller writers. This is a classic British mystery that absolutely bristles with suspense.

results.title: The Shop on Main Street = The Shop on the high street = Obchad na korze (NTSC)
results.creator_credit: Elmar Klos, Jan Kadar, Ceskoslovensky Filmexport and Filmove Studio Barrandov
results.brief_description: The film is set during World War II in the ‘independent’ fascist Slovak statelet. It concerns Tono Brtko, a carpenter who is appointed ‘Aryan controller’ of a button shop by his fascist brother-in-law. The shop is owned by the Jewish Frau Lautmann, who is not only elderly but deaf and short-sighted, and thinks that Tono is her new assistant. Through a mixture of weakness, vacillation and decency, he fails to disabuse her, and a mutually beneficial relationship develops. This is an extraordinarily effective picture of ‘everyday fascism’ in a small community, and although it revolves around a grim and tragic theme, it is played largely as a gentle comedy. Cast includes Ida Kaminska, Jozef Kroner, Hana Slivkova and Frantisek Zvarik. In Czech with English subtitles.

results.title: Last orders
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Elizabeth Robinson, MPB, Scala Productions and Winchester Films
results.brief_description: Effortlessly moving between World War II and contemporary London, “Last Orders” is a film about friendship, honour and familial ties. Jack Dodd’s three best friends, and his son (played by Ray Winstone), are taking his ashes from London to Margate for the burial that Jack has demanded. His wife, Amy (Helen Mirren), has refused to go along for the ride: her journey takes the form of bittersweet remembrance of the betrayals, joys and comforts which are part of a lifelong marriage. Schepisi creates a perfectly realistic evocation of both old age and the passionate desires and dreamings of youth. “Last Orders” is in fact a peculiar kind of road movie in which the most important part of the journey is across time, and one in which the characters and personalities of the travellers are much more important than the dour suburbia through which they travel. At the heart of the film is Michael Caine’s Oscar nominated performance as Jack Dodd but he is ably supported by a superlative cast of British character actors. By placing actors such as Caine, Tom Courtenay and David Hemmings in a film about aging, death and grief, Schepisi also creates a loving memorial to the golden age of British cinema - the tough working class films of the early sixties which smashed the genteel pretensions of an earlier British cinema (though gentility was to arise again in the period dramas which now form the backbone of British television). “Last Orders” is based on the award winning novel by Graham Swift.

results.title: The Pledge
results.creator_credit: Sean Penn, Elie Samaha, Michael Fitzgerald and Pledge Productions
results.brief_description: Sean Penn’s third film behind the camera (The Indian runner, The Crossing guard) sees Jack Nicholson reprising his role as a man intent on keeping his word, in this case a promise to the mother of a murder victim to locate her daughter’s killer. Jerry Black (Nicholson) is about to retire when he becomes involved in one last case. The victim is a young girl found murdered in the snow, wearing a red dress and with suspected sexual interference. A witness identifies a man fleeing from the crime and is brought in, confessing before committing suicide. Black believes the girl is the victim of a serial killer and pledges to her mother that he will ensure the perpetrator is found. Continuing his retirement, Black purchases a petrol station in the mountains and begins a relationship with a single mother who has a daughter who fits the profile of the elusive killer that Black begins to call “The Giant”. There is an ensemble cast including Aaron Eckhart, Benicio Del Toro, Helen Mirren, Robin Wright Penn, Mickey Rourke and Harry Dean Stanton, however the film is all Nicholson’s as the obsessive, cautious protagonist who may or may not be pursuing a figment of his own imagination. Based on the book by Friedrich Durrenmatt.
